page.title: Penn State Nittany Lions men's volleyball

revisions.rev:
{{Infobox men's college volleyball team |name = Penn State Men's Volleyball |logo = |logo_size = 138 |university = Pennsylvania State University |conference = Eastern Intercollegiate Volleyball Association |conference_short = EIVA |division = |city = University Park |stateabb = PA |state = Pennsylvania |coach = [[Mark Pavlik]] |tenure = 16th |arena = [[Rec Hall]] |capacity = 7,200 |nickname = [[Penn State Nittany Lions|Nittany Lions]] |color1 = Blue |color2 = White |color3 = |fontcolor = ffffff |hex1 = 000099 |hex2 = FFFFFF |hex3 = |NCAAchampion = 1994, 2008 |NCAArunnerup = 1982, 1995, 2006, 2010 |NCAAtourneys = 1981, 1982, 1983, 1986, 1987, 1989, 1991, 1992, 1993, 1994, 1995, 1996, 1997, 1999, 2000, 2001, 2002, 2003, 2004, 2005, 2006, 2007, 2008, 2009, 2010 |conference_tournament = |conference_season = 1981, 1982, 1983, 1986, 1987, 1989, 1991, 1992, 1993, 1994, 1995, 1996, 1997, 1999, 2000, 2001, 2002, 2003, 2004, 2005, 2006, 2007, 2008, 2009, 2010 }}
'''[[Penn State]]''' has had a long tradition with their men's [[volleyball]] program. Founded in 1976 by Tom Tait, Tait coached the team from 1976â1989, and was named a [[USA Volleyball]] All-Time great coach in 2007.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.brevard.edu/LinkClick.aspx?fileticket=Rq6k6Pfe7WU%3D&tabid=158| title = Tom Tait awarded USA volleyball all-time great coach | last = | first = | date = 2007-08-07 | publisher = Brevard College | accessdate = 2008-07-07}}</ref>
[[Mark Pavlik]] has been the head coach since 1995 after serving as an assistant coach for five years. He has led the team to every [[EIVA]] conference championship since 1995 with the exception of 1998. Under his guidance, Penn State finished as NCAA runner-ups in 1995 and 2006 before winning it all in 2008. He also led the team to an NCAA record of 11 straight (1998â2009) NCAA final four appearances. Pavlik was awarded his first ever AVCA National Coach of the Year in 2008.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://gopsusports.cstv.com/sports/m-volley/spec-rel/052108aab.html| title = Mark Pavlik named AVCA National Coach of the Year | last = | first = | date = 2008-05-21 | publisher = Penn State Athletics | accessdate = 2008-05-24}}</ref>
==Results== ===1982=== Penn State made their first ever [[NCAA Men's Volleyball Championship|NCAA Championship match]] this year. Current head coach Mark Pavlik was a setter on the team.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.volleyball.com/questions/default.aspx?mode=blog&id=16&yearnum=2008&monthnum=6| title = Questions with Mark Pavlik | last = Phillips | first = Christine | date = 2008-06-11 | publisher = Volleyball.com | accessdate = 2008-07-19}}</ref> Penn State was swept by perennial powerhouse [[UCLA Bruins|UCLA]] in the final at [[Rec Hall]], led by future [[Olympic games|Olympic]] gold medalist and Most Outstanding Player [[Karch Kiraly]].
===1994=== 1994 was a historic year, as Penn State became the first non-[[California]] university to win the men's volleyball championship. Playing in [[Fort Wayne, Indiana]], the Lions defeated defending NCAA champion UCLA in a five-set match. After falling behind 2 sets to 1, UCLA looked to have the championship in their hands after being up 11-4 in the fourth set, needing to only get to 15. However, the Lions mounted a stunning comeback and went on a 11-1 run to take set four 15-12 and set five with the same score to win the national championship. It was then-head coach Tom Peterson's last year.
===1997=== Penn State got back to the final four, losing to UCLA in a five-set match in the semifinals. Senior [[Ivan Contreras]] was named the [[AVCA]] National Player of the Year, the first ever east coast player to win the award.
===2006=== After eight straight years of making the NCAA final four and losing in the semifinals, Penn State finally broke through. They defeated top ranked and top-seeded [[UC Irvine]] in the semifinals at [[Rec Hall]] in five games.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://gopsusports.cstv.com/sports/m-volley/spec-rel/050406aab.html| title = Men's volleyball stuns No. 1 UC Irvine | last = | first = | date = 2006-05-04 | publisher = Penn State Athletics | accessdate = 2008-06-30}}</ref> Despite the successful semifinal result, Penn State lost to UCLA in the national championship.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://gopsusports.cstv.com/sports/m-volley/spec-rel/050606aaa.html| title = UCLA claims 19th championship with sweep of Lions | last = | first = | date = 2006-05-06 | publisher = Penn State Athletics | accessdate = 2008-06-30}}</ref>
===2008=== [[Image:MattAnderson.jpeg|left|370px|thumb|[[Matt Anderson (volleyball)|Matt Anderson]] (above) was the 2008 [[AVCA]] National Player of the Year, [[EIVA]] Player of the Year, and [[NCAA Men's Volleyball Championship|NCAA championship tournament]] [[most valuable player]], and was an AVCA first-team [[All-America]].]] [[Image:PSU volleyball at the WH.jpg|225px|thumb|right|The Nittany Lions team, coaches, and staff are honored at the [[White House]] by [[President of the United States]] [[George W. Bush]] in June 2008 for the side's winning the 2008 [[NCAA Men's Volleyball Championship|national championship]].]]
In the early 2008 season, Penn State swept UCLA for the first time since 1991,<ref>[http://gopsusports.cstv.com/sports/m-volley/recaps/010508aaa.html No. 4 Penn State sweeps No. 3 UCLA]</ref> and also defeated west coast powers Hawai'i,<ref>[http://gopsusports.cstv.com/sports/m-volley/recaps/010408aaa.html No. 4 men's volleyball downs #11 Hawai'i]</ref> [[California Baptist University|Cal Baptist]]<ref>[http://gopsusports.cstv.com/sports/m-volley/recaps/031408aaa.html Penn State men's volleyball tops Cal Baptist, 3-0]</ref> and [[Long Beach State]].<ref>[http://gopsusports.cstv.com/sports/m-volley/recaps/031608aaa.html Penn State outlasts Long Beach State]</ref> Penn State only lost one match in the regular season to [[George Mason University|George Mason]],<ref>{{cite web | url = http://gopsusports.cstv.com/sports/m-volley/recaps/030708aaa.html| title = Top ranked Penn State falls to George Mason | last = | first = | date = 2008-03-07 | publisher = Penn State Athletics | accessdate = 2008-06-24}}</ref> but got revenge on the [[George Mason Patriots|Patriots]] in the [[EIVA]] tournament finals, securing their bid for their NCAA record 10th consecutive final four appearance. Penn State improved to 55-3 all time in the EIVA championship.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://gopsusports.cstv.com/sports/m-volley/recaps/042608aaa.html| title = Top ranked men's volleyball advances to NCAA Final Four | last = | first = | date = 2008-04-26 | publisher = Penn State Athletics | accessdate = 2008-06-24}}</ref>
Penn State was the top seed in the final four, the first time in the history of the men's volleyball tournament that a non-west coast university was the top seed.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://gopsusports.cstv.com/sports/m-volley/spec-rel/042708aaa.html| title = Top ranked men's volleyball number 1 seed in Final Four | last = | first = | date = 2008-04-27 | publisher = Penn State Athletics | accessdate = 2008-06-24}}</ref> The final four was held in [[Irvine, California]] at the [[Bren Events Center]] from May 1â3. After defeating [[Ohio State]] in the semifinals,<ref>[http://gopsusports.cstv.com/sports/m-volley/recaps/050108aac.html Penn State tops Ohio State, advances to NCAA championship]</ref> Penn State met [[Pepperdine University|Pepperdine]] in the final. After dropping the first game, Penn State went on to win the next three to defeat the [[Pepperdine#Athletics|Waves]] in four games. [[Matt Anderson (volleyball)|Matt Anderson]], the AVCA National Player of the Year, was named the Most Outstanding Player and also was an AVCA First Team All-American.<ref>[http://gopsusports.cstv.com/sports/m-volley/recaps/050308aaa.html Penn State men's volleyball beats Pepperdine, wins national championship]</ref> Four other Penn State players were named All-Americans.<ref>[http://gopsusports.cstv.com/sports/m-volley/spec-rel/042808aab.html No. 1 Men's volleyball earns five All-America awards]</ref>
Pepperdine head coach [[Marv Dunphy]] said earlier in the NCAA tournament that the 2008 Penn State men's volleyball team was the best men's volleyball team to ever come out of the east or midwest.<ref>{{cite web | url =http://www.volleyballmag.com/archive/2008/NittanyLion.php| title = The Year of the Nittany Lion | last =Miazga | first =Mike | date = 2008-05-04 | publisher = ''Volleyball Magazine''| accessdate = 2008-06-24}}</ref>
On July 1, 2008, Matt Anderson announced he would forgo his 2009 senior year to play professionally in Korea.<ref>{{cite web | url =http://www.centredaily.com/news/breaking_news/story/690654.html| title = Matt Anderson turning pro - in Korea | last =Brunskill | first =Jordan | date = 2008-07-01 | publisher = ''Centre Daily Times''| accessdate = 2008-07-19}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
==AVCA Awards== ===All-Americans=== For the men's volleyball program, 24 players have earned 36 All-America honors, including 14 selections to First Team. {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year ! All-Americans |- | 1991 | Scott Miller, Jorge Perez |- | 1993 | David Muir |- | 1994 | [[Ramon Hernandez (beach volleyball player)|Ramon Hernandez]]**, [[Ivan Contreras]] |- | 1995 | Ivan Contreras**, Carlos Ortiz**, Ed Josefoski |- | 1996 | Ivan Contreras**, Kevin Hourican |- | 1997 | Ivan Contreras**, Jason Kepner |- | 2001 | Jose Quinones** |- | 2002 | Jose Quinones**, Zelimir Koljesar, Ricky Mattei, Zach Slenker |- | 2003 | Carlos Guerra, Keith Kowal |- | 2004 | Keith Kowal**, Ricky Mattei |- | 2005 | Keith Kowal, Nate Meerstein, Matt Proper |- | 2006 | Matt Proper |- | 2007 | [[Matt Anderson (volleyball)|Matt Anderson]] |- | 2008 | Matt Anderson**, Max Holt**, Dennis Del Valle, Max Lipsitz, Luke Murray |- | 2009 | Max Holt**, Max Lipsitz**, Will Price**, Dennis Del Valle, Edgardo Goas |- | 2010 | Max Lipsitz**, Dennis Del Valle |}
<nowiki>**</nowiki> denotes First Team selection
===National awards===
Pavlik has earned one National Coach of the Year award, while former head coach Tom Peterson got the accolade once as well. Two Penn State players have been named Player of the Year.
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Year ! National Coach of the Year ! National Player of the Year |- | 1994 | Tom Peterson | |- | 1997 | | [[Ivan Contreras]] |- | 2008 | Mark Pavlik | [[Matt Anderson (volleyball)|Matt Anderson]] |}
